author: Mona Chalabi
title: A National Pizza Day investigation: how many slices a day do Americans eat? | Life and style
text:
Pizza truly is America’s national food, statistically speaking. That’s not because one in eight people in the US over the age of two will eat pizza on any given day. It’s because, unlike other food groups, the chance an American will eat a slice doesn’t vary much by gender or race.
The world's longest pizza – in pictures Read more 
Today is National Pizza Day, so we took a look at data from the US Department of Agriculture (USDA). Their most recent pizza study , published in 2014, shows that 21% of white Americans aged 2 to 19 will eat pizza on any given day; for black and Hispanic Americans, that figure is almost identical, at 20%. Men eat more pizza than women, but not by much: 15% of men, compared to 11% of women.
The only factor which seems to affect pizza intake is age. Americans aged 6 to 19 are four times more likely to be found eating pizza than those over 60. The USDA also asks people to complete detailed food diaries to find out what they are eating when. Pizza for dinner is uncommon – most people eat pizza as a snack (59%) or as lunch (28%), and 2% of the country eats it as breakfast.
It’s National Pizza Day and some of you monsters have been celebrating before lunch. Many other food groups look very different in the numbers. Take soda, for example: Americans consume more cola than juice, but that varies significantly by race and income. Black and Mexican adults get 60% more of their calories from sugary drinks than white Americans.
Facebook Twitter Pinterest 26.3% of American adults drink soda or sweetened fruit drinks at least once a day. But that percentage is higher if you’re under 34 years old, non-white or male. 
Source: US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Illustration by Mona Chalabi 
There isn’t much historical data available on pizza consumption. So we looked for clues elsewhere. The USDA has data going back to 1909 showing how much of which cheeses have been consumed. Overall, total cheese consumption has risen remarkably, but one stands out: per capita consumption of mozzarella was seven times higher in 1994 than it was in 1970.
